div.p: Unit 15, p. 153, VPRS 4025/P Town Clerk's letter press copy books, VA 511 Melbourne, Public Record Office, Victoria.
See also M to E. FitzGibbon, 28 April and 2 May 1869, in which M reiterates his complaints about rabbits. Town Hall Melbourne

Though too busy to answer your notes relative to animals set loose upon the Yarra bank, I have lost no time in sending to the place and ordering the immediate removal of the creatures, and that no others of a description likely to cause mischief should be brought there. I have since receiving your note this morning written a peremptory [note] to Mr Edwards to destroy immediately any rabbits which he may have at his place.
On 3 May FitzGibbon wrote to J. Edwards, Yarra Bank: 'Dr Von Mueller the Director of the Melbourne Botanic Garden has complained to me of the keeping of an Ass upon the south bank of the Yarra as I am informed by you and also that rabbits have been brought there and as I am also informed by you I have been informed that the Ass has since been removed but Dr Von Mueller tells me by letter of this day's date that some of the rabbits were seen at the boathouses yesterday. I have to require you forthwith to remove or destroy these creatures and to remark upon the extreme impropriety of bringing them to a place where they are likely to do such incalculable damage to the public property' (Unit 15, p. 149, VPRS 4025/P, PROV).

I am informed in respect to Mr Fuller
See M to E. FitzGibbon, 20 April 1869, in which M complains about the damage animals have done to trees because they are not fenced in at the premises of a boat-builder. that upon receiving the message from me at your instance to fence at the back of his boat house, he went to the offices of the Department of Crown Lands and was there told to disregard any directions other than such as should be sent from that Department. If this be so, I think it a pity that public bodies and officers who should have for their common object the improvement of the public property for the public advantage and enjoyment should take up a position of apparent antagonism.
